summary.html: added some NIST-ASTM standard test arena models that were previously available through the hector_nist_arenas_gazebo stack. Usability through model drag and drop will improve once grid snapping can be modified to a 1.2m spacing as requested in ticket #145 for gazebo.

values.description:
Prior to [Gazebo Pull Request #160](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/160), the hokuyo and camera models had gravity disabled since they do not contain a collision element. As discussed in [Gazebo Issue 274](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/274), it was decided that that should not be the default behavior for links without collision elements, but that they should explicitly disable gravity instead. This patch accompanies this change to Gazebo.

I tested using a box collision elements for these sensors, but the contacts cause jitter in the orientation that is very noticeable in the sensor output. I decided it was simpler to restore the previous behavior by explicitly disabling gravity.
values.title: Disable gravity for hokuyo and camera

summary.raw:
Prior to [Gazebo Pull Request #160](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/160), the hokuyo and camera models had gravity disabled since they do not contain a collision element. As discussed in [Gazebo Issue 274](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/274), it was decided that that should not be the default behavior for links without collision elements, but that they should explicitly disable gravity instead. This patch accompanies this change to Gazebo.

I tested using a box collision elements for these sensors, but the contacts cause jitter in the orientation that is very noticeable in the sensor output. I decided it was simpler to restore the previous behavior by explicitly disabling gravity.
summary.html:
Prior to Gazebo Pull Request #160, the hokuyo and camera models had gravity disabled since they do not contain a collision element. As discussed in Gazebo Issue 274, it was decided that that should not be the default behavior for links without collision elements, but that they should explicitly disable gravity instead. This patch accompanies this change to Gazebo.

I tested using a box collision elements for these sensors, but the contacts cause jitter in the orientation that is very noticeable in the sensor output. I decided it was simpler to restore the previous behavior by explicitly disabling gravity.

values.description:
It has the wheels, a chassis plate, the seat (with back), the cargo box, the engine, and a very simple steering wheel.

The steering wheel will need the most improvement: it's just 3 cylinders representing the internal structure of the wheel.

Also, I didn't put the steering wheel on a joint.

summary.raw:
It has the wheels, a chassis plate, the seat (with back), the cargo box, the engine, and a very simple steering wheel.

The steering wheel will need the most improvement: it's just 3 cylinders representing the internal structure of the wheel.

Also, I didn't put the steering wheel on a joint.
summary.html:
It has the wheels, a chassis plate, the seat (with back), the cargo box, the engine, and a very simple steering wheel.

The steering wheel will need the most improvement: it's just 3 cylinders representing the internal structure of the wheel.

Also, I didn't put the steering wheel on a joint.

values.description:
There appeared to be a bug with the polaris when used with the DRCVehiclePlugin controller ([drcsim issue 103](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/103)), but it appears to have been caused by astronomical friction values at the wheels. The vehicle was starting to slip and the high friction would cause it to stop completely. Reducing the wheel friction to 1.0 prevents the sudden stops, and introduces more realistic wheel slip.

I also raised polaris c.g. height to an estimated 0.4 m, since it was at ground level.
values.title: Polaris parameter tweaks, fix for drcsim issue 103

summary.raw:
There appeared to be a bug with the polaris when used with the DRCVehiclePlugin controller ([drcsim issue 103](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/103)), but it appears to have been caused by astronomical friction values at the wheels. The vehicle was starting to slip and the high friction would cause it to stop completely. Reducing the wheel friction to 1.0 prevents the sudden stops, and introduces more realistic wheel slip.

I also raised polaris c.g. height to an estimated 0.4 m, since it was at ground level.
summary.html:
There appeared to be a bug with the polaris when used with the DRCVehiclePlugin controller (drcsim issue 103), but it appears to have been caused by astronomical friction values at the wheels. The vehicle was starting to slip and the high friction would cause it to stop completely. Reducing the wheel friction to 1.0 prevents the sudden stops, and introduces more realistic wheel slip.

I also raised polaris c.g. height to an estimated 0.4 m, since it was at ground level.

values.reason: There's outstanding issues with the DRCVehiclePlugin that I'd prefer to resolve before changing these parameters.

values.description:
The steering wheel is raised to make it easier for Atlas to fit in the Polaris. The steering wheel also has visuals that rotate with the steering wheel.

The collision shape for the seat is lowered as well.

The roll bar and side handles now have simple collision shapes.

![Side view](https://dl.dropbox.com/u/96660379/atlas_polaris_side.png)

![Top view](https://dl.dropbox.com/u/96660379/atlas_polaris_top.png)

Retargeted to default

UPDATE:

* merge with default, fix steering wheel axis
* Update contact parameters for wheels, seat
* Reduce size of door handles
* Reduced size of wheel well in visual mesh
* Added collision shape for side body panel near wheel well
* Fixed wheel friction, added wheel camber to give 1 contact point on flat ground, fixed steering wheel inertia

![new door handles](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/door_handles.jpg)

![new collision shapes](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/polaris_collisions.jpg)
values.title: Polaris: raise steering wheel, add collision shapes for roll cage and handles

The collision shape for the seat is lowered as well.

![Side view](https://dl.dropbox.com/u/96660379/atlas_polaris_side.png)

![Top view](https://dl.dropbox.com/u/96660379/atlas_polaris_top.png)

Retargeted to default

UPDATE:

* merge with default, fix steering wheel axis
* Update contact parameters for wheels, seat
* Reduce size of door handles
* Reduced size of wheel well in visual mesh
* Added collision shape for side body panel near wheel well
* Fixed wheel friction, added wheel camber to give 1 contact point on flat ground, fixed steering wheel inertia

![new door handles](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/door_handles.jpg)

![new collision shapes](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/polaris_collisions.jpg)
summary.html:
The steering wheel is raised to make it easier for Atlas to fit in the Polaris. The steering wheel also has visuals that rotate with the steering wheel.

The collision shape for the seat is lowered as well.

The roll bar and side handles now have simple collision shapes.

Retargeted to default

UPDATE:

  • merge with default, fix steering wheel axis
  • Update contact parameters for wheels, seat
  • Reduce size of door handles
  • Reduced size of wheel well in visual mesh
  • Added collision shape for side body panel near wheel well
  • Fixed wheel friction, added wheel camber to give 1 contact point on flat ground, fixed steering wheel inertia

values.description:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

* #!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

### Changelist: ###

* added texture to mud

* improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

* added randomized texture to rubble

* changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see [gazebo issue 572](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/572/vrc-heightmap-problems))

* replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

* added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

* removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

* turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

* added brick texture to starting pen

* added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

* changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

### Pictures of new arenas:###

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas
values.title: New VRC Textures

summary.html:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff
  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff
  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

Changelist:

  • added texture to mud

  • improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

  • added randomized texture to rubble

  • changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see gazebo issue 572)

  • replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

  • added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

  • removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

  • turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

  • added brick texture to starting pen

  • added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

  • changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

Pictures of new arenas:

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas
